channel.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India
channel.description: World News: TOI brings the latest world news headlines, Current International breaking news world wide. In depth analysis and top news headlines world wide.

image.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: 'Constitution is being mocked': PTI vice chairman Qureshi on upcoming elections
item.description: Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) Vice Chairman Shah Mahmood Qureshi has criticised the upcoming general elections, referring to them as 'mock elections' and deeming the process a waste of money. Qureshi said, "Democracy is being strangled and the Constitution is being mocked." He urged Chief Justice of Pakistan and the chief election commissioner to address PTI's demand for a level playing field.

item.title: 'Pak must end disappearances, extrajudicial killings in Baloch, Sindh'
item.description: US Congressman Brad Sherman urged Pakistan to end enforced disappearances and extrajudicial killings in Balochistan and Sindh regions. He highlighted the case of MahRang Baloch, a human rights activist, whose father was abducted and found dead. Sherman emphasized the importance of addressing human rights breaches in Pakistan and warned that such practices could destroy the country's moral foundation.

item.title: US President Joe Biden pledges to stand up to antisemitism
item.description: US President Joe Biden has sworn to combat antisemitism and promised "never again" while recognizing what Jewish Holocaust survivors have gone through. Biden stated that the US joins nations across the world in mourning "one of the darkest chapters in human history," grieving lives murdered by Nazis and honoring survivors and those who risked their lives for the innocent.

item.title: Farmers vow Paris 'siege' in pay, conditions battle
item.description: Farmers in the Paris region, belonging to the FNSEA farmers' union or the Jeunes Agriculteurs, will siege the French capital, demanding better pay, tax relief, and regulations. They will block major roads leading to Paris, while farmers from Lot-et-Garonne plan to blockade the Rungis wholesale food market.

item.title: North Korea fired multiple cruise missiles - South Korea military
Alaska Airlines has begun flying Boeing Max 9 jetliners again for the first time Friday
item.description: Alaska Airlines has resumed flying Boeing 737 Max 9 jetliners after they were grounded due to a door plug panel blowing out during a flight. The airline completed final inspections and resumed flights from Seattle to San Diego. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) approved the inspection and maintenance process, allowing Alaska and United Airlines.

item.title: Trump praises Texas governor as border state clashes with Biden administration over immigration
item.description: Former President Donald Trump praises Texas Gov. Greg Abbott for not allowing the Biden administration to remove razor wire along the US-Mexico border. Trump promises to send reinforcements to Texas instead of restraining orders. He avoids discussing the recent verdict in a defamation case and accuses the Biden administration of weaponizing law enforcement against him.

item.title: Circus animals rescued after truck catches fire on Indiana highway
item.description: A truck carrying zebras and camels for a circus caught fire on an Indiana highway. The animals were rescued by law enforcement officers and none were injured. The circus, a fundraiser for the Mizpah Shrine Circus, went on as planned at Fort Wayne's Memorial Coliseum.

item.title: Netanyahu is defiant after UN court ruling, says Israel presses offensive for 'complete victory'
Israel bulldozes swathes of Gaza
China urges US to refrain from backing Taiwan independence
item.description: Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi told US national security adviser Jake Sullivan that Washington should stand by a commitment not to support independence for Taiwan, during their high-level talks in the Thai capital, the Chinese foreign ministry said Saturday. Wang said Taiwan's recent election didn't change the fact that the island is part of China and the biggest challenge in US-China relations is the issue of "Taiwan independence"

item.title: Russia unable to prove POW plane crash claims: Kyiv
item.description: Officials in Ukraine said Russia has provided no credible evidence to back its claims that Ukrainian forces shot down a military transport plane that Moscow says was carrying Ukrainian prisoners of war who were to be swapped for Russian POWs.The agency that deals with prisoner exchanges said late Friday that Russian officials had "with great delay" provided it with a list of the 65 Ukrainians who Moscow said had died in the plane crash in Russia's Belgorod region on Wednesday.

item.title: South Gaza battles rage as heavy rain hits displaced further north
item.description: Israel continues its campaign against Hamas in Gaza's Khan Younis despite bad weather affecting displaced Palestinians. Heavy aerial and tank fire reported in Khan Younis, where Hamas fighters fired an anti-tank missile at an Israeli tank. Israeli military kills at least 11 gunmen and engages with others firing rifles and rocket-propelled grenades.

item.title: Alabama's new execution method: What is nitrogen hypoxia?
item.description: Alabama successfully executed Kenneth Smith, who spent decades on death row, using nitrogen hypoxia, a new method. This method involves forcing Smith to inhale pure nitrogen through a respirator mask, which increases the concentration of nitrogen in his body to lethal levels, depriving tissues and organs of oxygen. This execution method was used after the failed attempts of lethal injection.

item.title: In stunning verdict, jury orders Trump to pay victim $83 million in rape defamation case
item.description: Trump has repeatedly denied the allegation that he sexually assaulted Carroll in a department store dressing room in 1996, but the jury determined that in course of his rebuttal he had disparaged her, and ordered him to pay her $7.3 million for "emotional harm," $11 million for "reputational damages," and $65 million in "punitive damages."

item.title: Fire exchanged between carrier and skiff in Arabian Sea, Ambrey and UKMTO say
item.description: "The skiff closed to 300 metres, before turning back towards a mothership," security firm Ambrey said in an advisory note, adding that the carrier and its crew were reported to be safe. It said the incident took place 700 nautical miles southeast of Salalah in Oman.

item.title: Airstrike kills 3 Palestinians in southern Gaza as Israel presses on with its war against Hamas
item.description: Israel conducts airstrike in Gaza despite the International Court of Justice's order to prevent death and destruction. South Africa accuses Israel of genocide against Palestinians as war death toll rises to 26,257. Israel continues the offensive, hostages remain in Gaza. The ministry does not distinguish between combatants and civilians in its count, but has said about two-thirds are women and children.

item.title: Venezuela's highest court upholds ban on opposition presidential candidate
item.description: The Venezuelan government frequently bans adversaries from public office, including in presidential contests. The court upheld bans on opposition candidates Freddy Superlano and Henrique Capriles. The bans are part of a pattern of sidelining adversaries.

item.title: Lost 'Gustav Klimt' portrait found after almost a century
item.description: Austrian artist Gustav Klimt's long-lost 'Portrait of Fraulein Lieser' has been found in Vienna after almost a century. The painting, which belonged to a Jewish family in Austria, will be auctioned on April 24 and is expected to fetch over $54 million. This rediscovery is considered a sensation and the painting's rarity and artistic significance have made it highly valuable.

item.title: Tuvalu's prime minister reportedly loses his seat in crucial elections on the Pacific island nation
item.description: The proposed security treaty between Tuvalu and Australia could hang in the balance. The treaty commits Australia to help Tuvalu in response to major natural disasters, health pandemics, and military aggression. The election outcome has implications for China, Taiwan, and Australia, and the fate of the proposed security treaty between Tuvalu and Australia hangs in the balance.
